page.title: 10SOCIAL LIFE IN THIS AREA
page.content: destroyed the flora, fauna and topo- graphy of the area. The appearance of the land surrounding the village became unfamiliar. Not only well- loved faces had gone. Now well-known landmarks, building and childhood haunts had disappeared forever. Mothers sought work outside the home. This led to increased wealth, but it was responsible for an change in the upbringing of families. Television and video curtailed family conver- sation. Supermarkets affected the trade of local shopkeepers, and the possession of family cars or money to hire taxis was to influence local bus services in the revision of time- tables. Three chapels and a church have survived, and a handful of the original villagers remain, but most of them now lie at rest in the churchyard of St. Cuthbert, Etherley.
